elements.content: Depending on the experimental conditions, the solid-state reactions of CuI with pyrazine (pyz) yield three distinct coordination polymers (CPs): a double chain polymer [Cu2I2(pyz)] n (yellow powder) and a single strand [CuI­(pyz)] n (red powder) and its new isomeric compound [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n (orange powder), which present dimers of CuI bridged by the pyrazine ligands. The conversions among the three CPs were studied: by heating to 110 °C, [CuI­(pyz)] n or [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n convert into [Cu2I2(pyz)] n , which reverts to the starting compounds upon kneading or grinding in the presence of pyrazine. The orange isomer [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n is obtained only when the solid-state reaction is performed with neat grinding or by direct melting of the pyrazine; it is unstable in the presence of solvent or vapor, and it readily transforms into the red isomer. The structure of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n was determined by X-ray powder diffraction. [Cu2I2(pyz)] n reacts also with 4-cyanopyrazine to yield the mixed ligand compound [(CuI)­(4CN-py)2 py] n , which, when heated, decomposes into [Cu2I2(pyz)] n and [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n.
elements.clean_text: Depending on the experimental conditions, the solid-state reactions of CuI with pyrazine (pyz) yield three distinct coordination polymers (CPs): a double chain polymer [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  (yellow powder) and a single strand [CuI(pyz)] n  (red powder) and its new isomeric compound [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  (orange powder), which present dimers of CuI bridged by the pyrazine ligands. The conversions among the three CPs were studied: by heating to 110 °C, [CuI(pyz)] n  or [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  convert into [Cu2I2(pyz)] n , which reverts to the starting compounds upon kneading or grinding in the presence of pyrazine. The orange isomer [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  is obtained only when the solid-state reaction is performed with neat grinding or by direct melting of the pyrazine; it is unstable in the presence of solvent or vapor, and it readily transforms into the red isomer. The structure of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  was determined by X-ray powder diffraction. [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  reacts also with 4-cyanopyrazine to yield the mixed ligand compound [(CuI)(4CN-py)2 py] n , which, when heated, decomposes into [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  and [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n.

elements.content: Let us grind! Mechanochemistry is more versatile and effective than the synthesis in solution, and in case of the reactions of copper iodide and pyrazine, three different coordination polymers were obtained by grinding/kneading. In particular, [(CuI)2 pyz2] n can be obtained only by grinding, and its structure was determined by powder X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text: Let us grind! Mechanochemistry is more versatile and effective than the synthesis in solution, and in case of the reactions of copper iodide and pyrazine, three different coordination polymers were obtained by grinding/kneading. In particular, [(CuI)2 pyz2] n  can be obtained only by grinding, and its structure was determined by powder X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) based on the combination of metal ions and ligands are interesting because of their potential applications as multifunctional and multistimuli responsive materials. In the case of luminescent materials, the final properties can be tuned by an appropriate choice of ligand bridges and metal coordination nodes. In this respect, the quest for more sustainable materials is driving toward the use of coinage metals, which are cheaper and more environmentally friendly than Ir, Pt, and rare-earth metal ions. Among these, the family of copper­(I) halides and pseudohalides is particularly attractive due to its large variety of photophysical properties associated with an extremely high structural diversity, which allows to obtain several different compounds starting from the same reagents. This latter feature implies, as a drawback, that the final structure of the coordination polymer based on Cu­(I) is difficult to design or in some cases to obtain as pure material due to mixture formation. For instance, there are not less than 14 different structures in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) based on CuI and diazabicyclo octane (DABCO), which differ in stoichiometry, nuclearity of the CuI core, and nature of encapsulated solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) based on the combination of metal ions and ligands are interesting because of their potential applications as multifunctional and multistimuli responsive materials. In the case of luminescent materials, the final properties can be tuned by an appropriate choice of ligand bridges and metal coordination nodes. In this respect, the quest for more sustainable materials is driving toward the use of coinage metals, which are cheaper and more environmentally friendly than Ir, Pt, and rare-earth metal ions. Among these, the family of copper(I) halides and pseudohalides is particularly attractive due to its large variety of photophysical properties associated with an extremely high structural diversity, which allows to obtain several different compounds starting from the same reagents. This latter feature implies, as a drawback, that the final structure of the coordination polymer based on Cu(I) is difficult to design or in some cases to obtain as pure material due to mixture formation. For instance, there are not less than 14 different structures in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) based on CuI and diazabicyclo octane (DABCO), which differ in stoichiometry, nuclearity of the CuI core, and nature of encapsulated solvent molecules.

elements.content: The synthetic conditions, especially the presence of the solvent and the stoichiometry ratio between reactants, appear to play a fundamental role in determining the nature of the final product. In general, reactions performed with an excess of ligand favor the formation of low-nuclearity compounds such as dimers, while an excess of copper­(I) halide promotes the formation of infinite arrangements of CuX. Less explored has been, however, the effect of moving from solution to solid-state mechanochemical reaction conditions. In the strive for more sustainable eco-friendly approach to synthetic procedures, the use of solventless methods, such as those based on the mechanical mixing of the reactants, has been demonstrated to be an attractive alternative.
elements.clean_text: The synthetic conditions, especially the presence of the solvent and the stoichiometry ratio between reactants, appear to play a fundamental role in determining the nature of the final product. In general, reactions performed with an excess of ligand favor the formation of low-nuclearity compounds such as dimers, while an excess of copper(I) halide promotes the formation of infinite arrangements of CuX. Less explored has been, however, the effect of moving from solution to solid-state mechanochemical reaction conditions. In the strive for more sustainable eco-friendly approach to synthetic procedures, the use of solventless methods, such as those based on the mechanical mixing of the reactants, has been demonstrated to be an attractive alternative.

elements.content: Mechanochemical methods have become increasingly popular in the field of crystal engineering and materials science, because they allow to explore reaction conditions that do not depend on the solubility of the reactants and/or of the products. Moreover, the diverse experimental conditions may lead to different results, which is exactly what we observed in the case of the reaction of CuI with pyrazine.
elements.clean_text: Mechanochemical methods have become increasingly popular in the field of crystal engineering and materials science, because they allow to explore reaction conditions that do not depend on the solubility of the reactants and/or of the products. Moreover, the diverse experimental conditions may lead to different results, which is exactly what we observed in the case of the reaction of CuI with pyrazine.

elements.content: The major drawback of a mechanochemical approach, however, remains the difficulty of ascertaining the structural features of the product, which is, necessarily, in the form of a polycrystalline powder ruling out the possibility of collecting single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. In these cases structure determination from powder data, could be the only available option to determine the crystal structure. The more recent developments in the mechanochemistry field also provide the possibility to follow the reaction in situ via X-ray diffraction techniques, monitoring the modification of the structure during the synthetic process.
elements.clean_text: The major drawback of a mechanochemical approach, however, remains the difficulty of ascertaining the structural features of the product, which is, necessarily, in the form of a polycrystalline powder ruling out the possibility of collecting single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. In these cases structure determination from powder data, could be the only available option to determine the crystal structure. The more recent developments in the mechanochemistry field also provide the possibility to follow the reaction in situ via X-ray diffraction techniques, monitoring the modification of the structure during the synthetic process.

elements.content: Infinite double chains based on copper halides or pseudohalides have been investigated for their luminescence and conductivity properties. Several papers describe the structures and behavior of CuX pyrazine compounds, and recently the missing structure of the [CuI­(pyz)] n (pyz = pyrazine) has been published. With the awareness that the copper iodide reacts easily via mechanochemistry, we investigated the possibility to obtain and transform the CuI pyrazine compounds upon mechanical and thermal treatments. We show that this approach allows not only to move in a “green” synthetic direction but also to discover compounds that would not be otherwise accessible by solution methods. Finally, we explored the possibility of substituting pyrazine with an alternative bridging ligand in coordination polymer formation.
elements.clean_text: Infinite double chains based on copper halides or pseudohalides have been investigated for their luminescence and conductivity properties. Several papers describe the structures and behavior of CuX pyrazine compounds, and recently the missing structure of the [CuI(pyz)] n  (pyz = pyrazine) has been published. With the awareness that the copper iodide reacts easily via mechanochemistry, we investigated the possibility to obtain and transform the CuI pyrazine compounds upon mechanical and thermal treatments. We show that this approach allows not only to move in a "green" synthetic direction but also to discover compounds that would not be otherwise accessible by solution methods. Finally, we explored the possibility of substituting pyrazine with an alternative bridging ligand in coordination polymer formation.

elements.content: Here we report that the previously known compounds [Cu2I2(pyz)] n and [CuI­(pyz)] n can be synthesized by kneading, also called liquid-assisted grinding (LAG), while the new coordination polymer [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n can be obtained by neat grinding, that is, in the absence of any solvent. Since [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n is produced only as a microcrystalline powder, the structure was determined by X-ray powder diffraction, and it is characterized by the presence of copper iodide dimers bridged by the pyrazine ligands. [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n transforms to the more stable isomer [CuI­(pyz)] n in the presence of solvents or humidity.
elements.clean_text: Here we report that the previously known compounds [Cu2I2(pyz)] n   and [CuI(pyz)] n   can be synthesized by kneading, also called liquid-assisted grinding (LAG), while the new coordination polymer [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  can be obtained by neat grinding, that is, in the absence of any solvent. Since [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  is produced only as a microcrystalline powder, the structure was determined by X-ray powder diffraction, and it is characterized by the presence of copper iodide dimers bridged by the pyrazine ligands. [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  transforms to the more stable isomer [CuI(pyz)] n  in the presence of solvents or humidity.

elements.content: We also show that 4-cyanopyridine (4CN-py) can be used to replace pyrazine affording the coordination polymer of formula [(CuI)2(pyz)­(4CN-pyz)] n , which upon thermal treatment loses pyrazine and converts into the known [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5].
elements.clean_text: We also show that 4-cyanopyridine (4CN-py) can be used to replace pyrazine affording the coordination polymer of formula [(CuI)2(pyz)(4CN-pyz)] n , which upon thermal treatment loses pyrazine and converts into the known [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5].

elements.content:
Mechanochemical syntheses and structural characterization, interconversion by thermal and mechanical treatments of the products, as well as the outcome of slurry experiments, are described.

Experimental Section

All glassware was dried in an oven set to a temperature of 80 °C for 24 h prior to use. All reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. A Retsch MM200 ball mill was used for solid-state reaction, the mechano-syntheses were performed in 5 mL steel jars with two steel spheres (Ø = 5 mm, 0.505 g) inside; no grinding media was added. The quantities of the reagents were adjusted to have a complete conversion of the CuI into the final product; excess pyrazine can be easily removed by gently heating or under low pressure; all the mechanochemical reactions are considered quantitative, as no CuI peaks are visible in the diffraction patterns of the products.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanochemical syntheses and structural characterization, interconversion by thermal and mechanical treatments of the products, as well as the outcome of slurry experiments, are described.

Experimental Section

All glassware was dried in an oven set to a temperature of 80 °C for 24 h prior to use. All reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. A Retsch MM200 ball mill was used for solid-state reaction, the mechano-syntheses were performed in 5 mL steel jars with two steel spheres (Ø = 5 mm, 0.505 g) inside; no grinding media was added. The quantities of the reagents were adjusted to have a complete conversion of the CuI into the final product; excess pyrazine can be easily removed by gently heating or under low pressure; all the mechanochemical reactions are considered quantitative, as no CuI peaks are visible in the diffraction patterns of the products.

elements.content: CuI (0.788 mmol; 0.150 g) and pyrazine (0.394 mmol; 0.031 g) were ground together with ∼0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz, with a ball-to-powder mass ratio (BPR) of 10:1.8. The yellow crystalline powder obtained was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cu2I2(pyz)]n 

Solid-State Reaction

CuI (0.788 mmol; 0.150 g) and pyrazine (0.394 mmol; 0.031 g) were ground together with ~0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz, with a ball-to-powder mass ratio (BPR) of 10:1.8. The yellow crystalline powder obtained was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

elements.content: Reaction in solution: [Cu2I2(pyz)] n was obtained following the procedure described in literature. CuI (300 mg, 1.57 mmol) dissolved in MeCN (20 mL) was added to a stirred solution of pyrazine (63 mg, 7.9 mmol) in MeCN (20 mL). A yellow precipitate formed immediately and was filtered off after the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The solid was dried in vacuo and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.
elements.clean_text: Reaction in solution: [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  was obtained following the procedure described in literature. CuI (300 mg, 1.57 mmol) dissolved in MeCN (20 mL) was added to a stirred solution of pyrazine (63 mg, 7.9 mmol) in MeCN (20 mL). A yellow precipitate formed immediately and was filtered off after the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The solid was dried in vacuo and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

elements.content: CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and pyrazine (2 mmol; 0.162 g) were ground together with ∼0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:3.5). The red crystalline powder obtained was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum to eliminate the unreacted pyrazine, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [CuI(pyz)]n 

Solid-State Reaction

CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and pyrazine (2 mmol; 0.162 g) were ground together with ~0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:3.5). The red crystalline powder obtained was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum to eliminate the unreacted pyrazine, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction used differs from the published one. CuI (0,25 mmol; 0.043 g), pyrazine (1 mmol; 0.080 g), and 0.4 mL of acetonitrile were placed in 8 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave, heated to 120 °C for 30 min, and then cooled.
elements.clean_text:
Solvothermal Reaction

The solvothermal reaction used differs from the published one. CuI (0,25 mmol; 0.043 g), pyrazine (1 mmol; 0.080 g), and 0.4 mL of acetonitrile were placed in 8 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave, heated to 120 °C for 30 min, and then cooled.

elements.content: CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and pyrazine (1.2 mmol; 0.100 g) were ground together for 40 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:2.9). The orange crystalline powder obtained was left under vacuum to eliminate the unreacted pyrazine and stored in a dry place to prevent the conversion to the [CuI­(pyz)] n isomer.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [(CuI)2(pyz)2]n 

Solid-State Reaction

CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and pyrazine (1.2 mmol; 0.100 g) were ground together for 40 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:2.9). The orange crystalline powder obtained was left under vacuum to eliminate the unreacted pyrazine and stored in a dry place to prevent the conversion to the [CuI(pyz)] n  isomer.

elements.content: CuI reacts with melted pyrazine to produce [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n . Regardless from the synthetic process, [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n is unstable, and the conversion to the red isomer was observed over time (one to two weeks).
elements.clean_text: CuI reacts with melted pyrazine to produce [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n . Regardless from the synthetic process, [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  is unstable, and the conversion to the red isomer was observed over time (one to two weeks).

elements.content: CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and 4-CNpy (1.5 mmol; 0.156 g) were ground together with ∼0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:3.5). The product is a yellow crystalline powder. The product was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5]n 

Solid-State Reaction

CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and 4-CNpy (1.5 mmol; 0.156 g) were ground together with ~0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:3.5). The product is a yellow crystalline powder. The product was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

elements.content: The product of [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n was obtained following the procedure described in literature. CuI (0.300 g, 1.57 mmol) dissolved in MeCN (20 mL) was added to a stirred solution of 4CN-py (0.204 g, 2 mmol) in MeCN (20 mL). A yellow precipitate formed immediately and was filtered off after the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The solid was dried under vacuum and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Reaction in Solution

The product of [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n  was obtained following the procedure described in literature. CuI (0.300 g, 1.57 mmol) dissolved in MeCN (20 mL) was added to a stirred solution of 4CN-py (0.204 g, 2 mmol) in MeCN (20 mL). A yellow precipitate formed immediately and was filtered off after the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The solid was dried under vacuum and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

elements.content: [Cu2I2(pyz)] n (1 mmol; 0.115 g) and 4-cyanopyridine (2 mmol; 0.052 g) were ground together with four drops of acetonitrile for 40 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:1.7). The product is a yellow crystalline powder. The product was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [(CuI)2(4CN-py)(pyz)]n 

Solid-State Reaction

[Cu2I2(pyz)] n  (1 mmol; 0.115 g) and 4-cyanopyridine (2 mmol; 0.052 g) were ground together with four drops of acetonitrile for 40 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:1.7). The product is a yellow crystalline powder. The product was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

elements.content:
Single crystals of [(CuI)2(4CN-py)­(pyz)] n were obtained by slow evaporation of an acetonitrile solution of [Cu2I2(pyz)] n and 4CN-py.

Slurry Experiments

A saturated solution of the starting material (the microcrystalline powder of the appropriate CuI-pyrazine coordination polymer) was prepared by using 1 mmol of powder and ∼0.5 mL of acetonitrile, making sure that part of the powder remained undissolved. Depending on the experiment, 1 equiv of CuI or 1.2 equiv of pyrazine was added in the solution, and the suspension was left stirring for at least 3 d. The powder was filtered and characterized by X-ray powder diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallization

Single crystals of [(CuI)2(4CN-py)(pyz)] n  were obtained by slow evaporation of an acetonitrile solution of [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  and 4CN-py.

Slurry Experiments

A saturated solution of the starting material (the microcrystalline powder of the appropriate CuI-pyrazine coordination polymer) was prepared by using 1 mmol of powder and ~0.5 mL of acetonitrile, making sure that part of the powder remained undissolved. Depending on the experiment, 1 equiv of CuI or 1.2 equiv of pyrazine was added in the solution, and the suspension was left stirring for at least 3 d. The powder was filtered and characterized by X-ray powder diffraction.

elements.content:
TGA measurements were performed using a PerkinElmer TGA7 in the temperature range of 35–400 °C under N2 gas flow, and heating was performed at 5 °C min–1.

X-ray Powder Diffraction

The data were collected in open air in Bragg–Brentano geometry using Cu Kα radiation without a monochromator. X-ray powder diffractograms were collected in the 2θ range of 5–50° using a Panalytical X’Pert PRO automated diffractometer equipped with an X’Celerator detector and an Anton Paar TTK 450 system for measurements at a controlled temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

TGA measurements were performed using a PerkinElmer TGA7 in the temperature range of 35-400 °C under N2 gas flow, and heating was performed at 5 °C min-1.

X-ray Powder Diffraction

The data were collected in open air in Bragg-Brentano geometry using Cu Kα radiation without a monochromator. X-ray powder diffractograms were collected in the 2θ range of 5-50° using a Panalytical X'Pert PRO automated diffractometer equipped with an X'Celerator detector and an Anton Paar TTK 450 system for measurements at a controlled temperature.

elements.content: The data of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n were collected with a Panalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer equipped with an Pixcel detector in transmission geometry with Cu Kα radiation without a monochromator. The sample was placed in 0.05 mm capillary, the 2θ range 10–85° (step size 0.013°, time/step 200 s, VxA 40 kV × 40 mA).
elements.clean_text:
Structure Determination from Powder Diffraction

The data of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  were collected with a Panalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer equipped with an Pixcel detector in transmission geometry with Cu Kα radiation without a monochromator. The sample was placed in 0.05 mm capillary, the 2θ range 10-85° (step size 0.013°, time/step 200 s, VxA 40 kV × 40 mA).

elements.content: The pattern was indexed with TOPAS, as a triclinic cell with a = 7.2730(3)­Å, b = 7.2912(3)­Å, c = 7.9513(2) Å, α = 112.297(2)°, β = 109.398(2)°, γ = 102.807(2)°. The volume of 337.52(2)­Å3 corresponds to two copper atoms, two iodine atoms, and two pyrazine molecules. The structure was solved in P1 space group with simulated annealing, and the structure found was converted to the P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit contains one copper atom, one iodine atom, and two half pyrazine molecules. The pyrazine molecules are forced to be on the inversion center by the use of a dummy atom at the center of the molecules, and the number of degree of freedom is minimized. The Rietveld refinement was carried out in the P1̅ space group. A shifted Chebyshev function with 11 parameters and four peaks was used to fit background and an impurity, respectively. TCHZ function was used to fit peak shape. All the hydrogen atoms were fixed in calculated positions. Refinement converged with R wp = 4.77%; R p = 3.78%, and R exp = 7.19% ().
elements.clean_text: The pattern was indexed with TOPAS, as a triclinic cell with a = 7.2730(3)Å, b = 7.2912(3)Å, c = 7.9513(2) Å, α = 112.297(2)°, β = 109.398(2)°, γ = 102.807(2)°. The volume of 337.52(2)Å3 corresponds to two copper atoms, two iodine atoms, and two pyrazine molecules. The structure was solved in P1 space group with simulated annealing, and the structure found was converted to the P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit contains one copper atom, one iodine atom, and two half pyrazine molecules. The pyrazine molecules are forced to be on the inversion center by the use of a dummy atom at the center of the molecules, and the number of degree of freedom is minimized. The Rietveld refinement was carried out in the P1̅ space group. A shifted Chebyshev function with 11 parameters and four peaks was used to fit background and an impurity, respectively. TCHZ function was used to fit peak shape. All the hydrogen atoms were fixed in calculated positions. Refinement converged with R wp = 4.77%; R p = 3.78%, and R exp = 7.19% ().

elements.content: Rietveld refinement of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n . Blue line is the experimental pattern, red line is the calculated pattern, gray line is the difference plot.
elements.clean_text: 1  Rietveld refinement of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n . Blue line is the experimental pattern, red line is the calculated pattern, gray line is the difference plot.

elements.content:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements (SCXD) were performed on an Oxford Xcalibur S diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.710 73 Å, and monochromator graphite at room temperature.

[(CuI)2(4CN-py)­(pyz)] n crystallizes as monoclinic P21/c with a = 10.2348(6) Å, b = 12.3289(4) Å, c = 8.8309(5) Å, and β = 109.605(6)° with volume 1049.73(9) Å3. SHELX97 was used for structure solution and refinement based on F 2. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were added in calculated positions. The refinement converged to R 1 (F, I > 2σ­(I) = 0.042 and WR2 (F 2, all data) = 0.136. The program Mercury was used for all graphical representations and for the calculated powder pattern. Additional crystallographic information is available in the .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements (SCXD) were performed on an Oxford Xcalibur S diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å, and monochromator graphite at room temperature.

[(CuI)2(4CN-py)(pyz)] n  crystallizes as monoclinic P21/c with a = 10.2348(6) Å, b = 12.3289(4) Å, c = 8.8309(5) Å, and β = 109.605(6)° with volume 1049.73(9) Å3. SHELX97 was used for structure solution and refinement based on F 2. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were added in calculated positions. The refinement converged to R 1 (F, I > 2σ(I) = 0.042 and WR2 (F 2, all data) = 0.136. The program Mercury was used for all graphical representations and for the calculated powder pattern. Additional crystallographic information is available in the .

elements.content: We reacted copper iodide with pyrazine in the solid state (with or without the presence of some drop of liquid) with the aim of investigating the possibility of obtaining new products via alternative synthetic routes with respect to solution. Furthermore, we explored the effect of varying the stoichiometry ratios and solvothermal procedures. On the one hand, we found that the coordination polymers [Cu2I2(pyz)] n and [CuI­(pyz)] n can be easily prepared by kneading of CuI and pyrazine in the appropriate stoichiometry ratios, while the absence of solvent during the milling allows the formation of the orange product [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n . The reactions in solution, on the other hand, yield exclusively yellow [Cu2I2(pyz)] n regardless of the stoichiometry ratio. Red crystals of [CuI­(pyz)] n can be obtained in solvothermal conditions. The results are detailed below.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

We reacted copper iodide with pyrazine in the solid state (with or without the presence of some drop of liquid) with the aim of investigating the possibility of obtaining new products via alternative synthetic routes with respect to solution. Furthermore, we explored the effect of varying the stoichiometry ratios and solvothermal procedures. On the one hand, we found that the coordination polymers [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  and [CuI(pyz)] n  can be easily prepared by kneading of CuI and pyrazine in the appropriate stoichiometry ratios, while the absence of solvent during the milling allows the formation of the orange product [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n . The reactions in solution, on the other hand, yield exclusively yellow [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  regardless of the stoichiometry ratio. Red crystals of [CuI(pyz)] n  can be obtained in solvothermal conditions. The results are detailed below.

elements.content: For the sake of the discussion, it is worth recalling the salient structural features of the [Cu2I2(pyz)] n and [CuI­(pyz)] n , which had been determined by Blake et. and by Malaestean et al., respectively. The structure of “yellow” [Cu2I2(pyz)] n is characterized by the presence of double polymeric chains with staircaselike arrangements of CuI in which the copper atoms, in tetrahedral coordination, bind three iodine atoms and one pyrazine molecule (a). The ligand acts as a bridge between two adjacent chains forming infinite two-dimensional (2D) sheets (b) stacked along the a-axis. The structure of “red” [CuI­(pyz)] n consists of “zigzag” chains of CuI in which the tetrahedral coordinated copper atoms bind two iodine atoms and two pyrazine molecules. The chains are linked together by the ligands that act as a bridge between two copper atoms forming an infinite 2D network (a). The crystal packing reveals the presence of a stacking along the b-axis of the chevronlike 2D sheets (b).
elements.clean_text: For the sake of the discussion, it is worth recalling the salient structural features of the [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  and [CuI(pyz)] n , which had been determined by Blake et. and by Malaestean et al., respectively. The structure of "yellow" [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  is characterized by the presence of double polymeric chains with staircaselike arrangements of CuI in which the copper atoms, in tetrahedral coordination, bind three iodine atoms and one pyrazine molecule (a). The ligand acts as a bridge between two adjacent chains forming infinite two-dimensional (2D) sheets (b) stacked along the a-axis. The structure of "red" [CuI(pyz)] n  consists of "zigzag" chains of CuI in which the tetrahedral coordinated copper atoms bind two iodine atoms and two pyrazine molecules. The chains are linked together by the ligands that act as a bridge between two copper atoms forming an infinite 2D network (a). The crystal packing reveals the presence of a stacking along the b-axis of the chevronlike 2D sheets (b).

elements.content: (a) The 2D network made of infinite double CuI chains bridged by the pyrazine molecules in [Cu2I2(pyz)] n . (b) View along the a axis showing the stacking of the infinite 2D sheets.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The 2D network made of infinite double CuI chains bridged by the pyrazine molecules in [Cu2I2(pyz)] n . (b) View along the a axis showing the stacking of the infinite 2D sheets.

elements.content: (a) The 2D network made of the infinite single-strain CuI chains bridged by the pyrazine molecules in [CuI­(pyz)] n . (b) View along the a-axis showing the chevronlike 2D sheets.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The 2D network made of the infinite single-strain CuI chains bridged by the pyrazine molecules in [CuI(pyz)] n . (b) View along the a-axis showing the chevronlike 2D sheets.

elements.content: These features ought to be compared with those of the novel compound, “orange” [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n , which does not present the copper iodide infinite chains observed before. Because of the polycrystalline nature of the mechanochemical product, its structure was determined from powder diffraction data (vide infra). The asymmetric unit consists of one copper atom, one iodine atom, and two independent half molecules of pyrazine. The copper atoms present a short Cu–Cu distance (2.648 (2) Å), and their tetrahedral coordination is fulfilled by two pyrazine ligands, which bridge two other dimers (a). The overall structure can be described as 2D coordination polymers stacked one on the others (b). The [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n presents a void volume of 4.4% (no solvent trapped inside as confirmed by the TGA analysis), and this could explain why it easily converts into the more stable isomer over time, readily in the presence of solvent or humidity. The coordination polymer is isostructural with the previously reported [(CuI)2(L)2] n (L = DABCO, and piperazine), which can also be obtained by solid-state reaction, but they show higher stability.

The copper atoms present a short Cu-Cu distance (2.648 (2) Å), and their tetrahedral coordination is fulfilled by two pyrazine ligands, which bridge two other dimers (a). The overall structure can be described as 2D coordination polymers stacked one on the others (b). The [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  presents a void volume of 4.4% (no solvent trapped inside as confirmed by the TGA analysis), and this could explain why it easily converts into the more stable isomer over time, readily in the presence of solvent or humidity. The coordination polymer is isostructural with the previously reported [(CuI)2(L)2] n  (L = DABCO, and piperazine), which can also be obtained by solid-state reaction, but they show higher stability.

elements.content: The existence of isomers of CuXL (X = halogen, L = organic ligand) is not unusual, and we already described some of them. In the reported cases the solvent used during the synthesis drives the formation of one or the other isomer, while [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n can be obtained only in absence of solvent; hence, common synthesis processes such as solution or solvothermal would not allow the formation this compound.
elements.clean_text: The existence of isomers of CuXL (X = halogen, L = organic ligand) is not unusual, and we already described some of them. In the reported cases the solvent used during the synthesis drives the formation of one or the other isomer, while [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  can be obtained only in absence of solvent; hence, common synthesis processes such as solution or solvothermal would not allow the formation this compound.

elements.content: As observed for [CuI­(pyz)] n , [Cu2I2(pyz)] n , also [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n is luminescent, and the emission and excitation spectra are reported in the Supporting Information (Figure SI 1 and Table SI 1). Investigations on the photophysical properties were not performed further.
elements.clean_text: As observed for [CuI(pyz)] n , [Cu2I2(pyz)] n , also [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  is luminescent, and the emission and excitation spectra are reported in the Supporting Information (Figure SI 1 and Table SI 1). Investigations on the photophysical properties were not performed further.

elements.content: We explored the possibilities of interconversion between the three coordination polymers by using different processes such as slurries and thermal and mechanical treatments. The interconversion between the compounds were easily detected by eye, because the compounds have different colors. The purity of the resulting solid phases was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (see ).
elements.clean_text:
Reversible Transformations between [CuI(pyz)]n, [Cu2I2(pyz)]n, and [(CuI)2(pyz)2]n 

We explored the possibilities of interconversion between the three coordination polymers by using different processes such as slurries and thermal and mechanical treatments. The interconversion between the compounds were easily detected by eye, because the compounds have different colors. The purity of the resulting solid phases was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (see ).

elements.content: Powder patterns. (top) [CuI­(pyz)] n Observed (red line) and calculated on the basis of the known structure (underlying black line), [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n observed (orange line, middle); [Cu2I2(pyz)] n observed (yellow line) and calculated on the basis of known structure (underlying black line, bottom).
elements.clean_text: 5  Powder patterns. (top) [CuI(pyz)] n  Observed (red line) and calculated on the basis of the known structure (underlying black line), [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  observed (orange line, middle); [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  observed (yellow line) and calculated on the basis of known structure (underlying black line, bottom).

elements.content: The TGA analyses of the two isomers have very similar results: in both cases the curves show loss of weight in two equal steps, the first at ∼110 °C and the second at 240 °C (a). We collected the pattern of the microcrystalline powders with variable-temperature X-ray powder diffraction, to understand the conversion. When heated, the orange [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n is stable up to 100 °C. Above 100 °C the compound releases pyrazine and transforms into yellow crystalline [Cu2I2(pyz)] n (b), which is stable up to 175 °C and finally decomposes into CuI. The red [CuI­(pyz)] n shows the same behavior as its isomer and as other isomorphic compounds by releasing one pyrazine at ∼110 °C and converting into the [Cu2I2(pyz)] n (see Figure SI2).
elements.clean_text: The TGA analyses of the two isomers have very similar results: in both cases the curves show loss of weight in two equal steps, the first at ~110 °C and the second at 240 °C (a). We collected the pattern of the microcrystalline powders with variable-temperature X-ray powder diffraction, to understand the conversion. When heated, the orange [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  is stable up to 100 °C. Above 100 °C the compound releases pyrazine and transforms into yellow crystalline [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  (b), which is stable up to 175 °C and finally decomposes into CuI. The red [CuI(pyz)] n  shows the same behavior as its isomer and as other isomorphic compounds by releasing one pyrazine at ~110 °C and converting into the [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  (see Figure SI2).

(b) XRPD-VT measurements for [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n . (○) The characteristic peaks of the starting material. (*) The peaks of [Cu2I2(pyz)] n .

elements.content: Almost all the reactions are reversible: by neat grinding [Cu2I2(pyz)] n with pyrazine (stoichiometry ratio 1:1) the pristine coordination polymer is obtained: the orange [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n by neat grinding and the red [CuI­(pyz)] n by kneading, while the isomers readily transform into [Cu2I2(pyz)] n by grinding with CuI. The conversion from [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n into [CuI­(pyz)] n is triggered by the presence of liquids or theirs vapors, but it is observed also over time; in ambient condition it converted in a week, but the time could change depending on the ambient temperature and humidity. This conversion suggests a higher thermodynamic stability of [CuI­(pyz)] n with respect to the other isomer, which is consistent with the idea that the most closed-packed structure is the most stable (density 2.754 vs 2.662 g/cm3). summarizes all the possible conversions.
elements.clean_text: Almost all the reactions are reversible: by neat grinding [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  with pyrazine (stoichiometry ratio 1:1) the pristine coordination polymer is obtained: the orange [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  by neat grinding and the red [CuI(pyz)] n  by kneading, while the isomers readily transform into [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  by grinding with CuI. The conversion from [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  into [CuI(pyz)] n  is triggered by the presence of liquids or theirs vapors, but it is observed also over time; in ambient condition it converted in a week, but the time could change depending on the ambient temperature and humidity. This conversion suggests a higher thermodynamic stability of [CuI(pyz)] n  with respect to the other isomer, which is consistent with the idea that the most closed-packed structure is the most stable (density 2.754 vs 2.662 g/cm3).  summarizes all the possible conversions.

Kn indicates kneading (also called LAG, liquid assisted grinding); G indicates grinding.

elements.content:
Kn indicates kneading (also called LAG, liquid assisted grinding); G indicates grinding.

Slurries experiments confirmed most of these interconversion processes, but they did not allow formation of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n , which can only be obtained in the absence of solvents. For this reason, it is possible to follow the diagram clockwise only by considering the mechanochemical reactions.
elements.clean_text:
a Kn indicates kneading (also called LAG, liquid assisted grinding); G indicates grinding.  

Slurries experiments confirmed most of these interconversion processes, but they did not allow formation of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n , which can only be obtained in the absence of solvents. For this reason, it is possible to follow the diagram clockwise only by considering the mechanochemical reactions.

elements.content: Considering the high degree of versatility of the solid-state processes involving CuI, in an attempt to prepare a mixed-ligand compound, we ground [Cu2I2(pyz)] n in the presence of 4-cyanopyridine affording the desired mixed ligand coordination polymer [(CuI)­(4CN-py)2 py] n . The direct neat grinding or kneading of CuI and 4CN-py, also in different stoichiometries, invariably afforded only the known compound [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n , characterized by an unusual stoichiometry compared also to the [CuX­(4CN-py)] n (X = Cl, Br), which forms a single-stranded infinite copper halide chain bridged by the organic ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Reactions with 4-Cyano Pyridine

Considering the high degree of versatility of the solid-state processes involving CuI, in an attempt to prepare a mixed-ligand compound, we ground [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  in the presence of 4-cyanopyridine affording the desired mixed ligand coordination polymer [(CuI)(4CN-py)2 py] n . The direct neat grinding or kneading of CuI and 4CN-py, also in different stoichiometries, invariably afforded only the known compound [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n , characterized by an unusual stoichiometry compared also to the [CuX(4CN-py)] n  (X = Cl, Br), which forms a single-stranded infinite copper halide chain bridged by the organic ligand.

elements.content: The structure of the mixed ligand [(CuI)­(4CN-py)2 py] n is characterized by the presence of Cu2I2 dimers with short Cu–Cu distance (2.606 (2)­Å) bridged by the pyrazine to form a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer (a). The 4-cyanopyridine coordinates the copper atom by the N-pyridine, and the −CN group is not involved in any interactions. The infinite chains run along the c axes, and the cyanopyridine ligands are interdigitated (b).
elements.clean_text: The structure of the mixed ligand [(CuI)(4CN-py)2 py] n  is characterized by the presence of Cu2I2 dimers with short Cu-Cu distance (2.606 (2)Å) bridged by the pyrazine to form a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer (a). The 4-cyanopyridine coordinates the copper atom by the N-pyridine, and the -CN group is not involved in any interactions. The infinite chains run along the c axes, and the cyanopyridine ligands are interdigitated (b).

elements.content: (a) The infinite chain of [(CuI)­(4CN-py)2 py] n with pyrazine bridging the copper iodide dimers and the 4CN-py almost perpendicular to the direction of the chain. (b) Packing view along the c axis.
elements.clean_text: 7  (a) The infinite chain of [(CuI)(4CN-py)2 py] n  with pyrazine bridging the copper iodide dimers and the 4CN-py almost perpendicular to the direction of the chain. (b) Packing view along the c axis.

elements.content: The TGA curve shows a weight loss in different steps, while variable-temperature diffraction shows that at ca. 120 °C [(CuI)­(4CN-py)2 py] n decomposes to form [Cu2I2(pyz)] n and [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n . The mixture is stable up to 150 °C when all the 4-CN-py is released, and the powder left contains [Cu2I2(pyz)] n and CuI (see ).
elements.clean_text: The TGA curve shows a weight loss in different steps, while variable-temperature diffraction shows that at ca. 120 °C [(CuI)(4CN-py)2 py] n  decomposes to form [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  and [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n . The mixture is stable up to 150 °C when all the 4-CN-py is released, and the powder left contains [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  and CuI (see ).

elements.content: XRPD-VT of [(CuI)­(4CN-py)2 py] n . The sample is stable up to 100 °C; at 120° the peaks characteristic of [Cu2I2(pyz)] n and [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n appear. The calculated patterns of the last two compounds are added to the diagram for comparison (labeled AGIYEU02 and KALHUA from the refcode of the CSD). At 150 °C the peak characteristic of CuI, at 2θ = 25 °C, is clearly visible.
elements.clean_text: 8  XRPD-VT of [(CuI)(4CN-py)2 py] n . The sample is stable up to 100 °C; at 120° the peaks characteristic of [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  and [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n  appear. The calculated patterns of the last two compounds are added to the diagram for comparison (labeled AGIYEU02 and KALHUA from the refcode of the CSD). At 150 °C the peak characteristic of CuI, at 2θ = 25 °C, is clearly visible.

elements.content: In this paper we have approached a well-known family of compounds, namely, the coordination polymers obtained by reaction of CuI and pyrazine, with a mechanochemical method. We were gratified by the discovery not only that the known [CuIpyz] n compound, obtained by solvothermal synthesis, can be easily and quantitatively obtained by kneading, but also that the same solid-state reaction performed by neat grinding yielded the previously unknown “orange” compound [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n . The structure of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n has been determined from powder diffraction data and shown to consist of discrete Cu2I2 dimers bridged by the pyrazine ligands to form a 2D network. The structure presents a 4.4% of void space, which makes the compound unstable, and in the presence of solvent or vapor it transforms into its isomer [CuIpyz] n also over time. We have also thoroughly explored the interconversion relationship between the three CuI derivatives. summarizes all the possible conversions among the three coordination polymers, via mechanochemistry, thermal treatment, and slurry. It is worth stressing that coordination based on CuI and pyrazine has been previously studied by several research groups without detecting the phase [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n , which represents a rather extreme example of a compound that can only be obtained by mechanical grinding of the reactants and in complete absence of solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper we have approached a well-known family of compounds, namely, the coordination polymers obtained by reaction of CuI and pyrazine, with a mechanochemical method. We were gratified by the discovery not only that the known [CuIpyz] n  compound, obtained by solvothermal synthesis, can be easily and quantitatively obtained by kneading, but also that the same solid-state reaction performed by neat grinding yielded the previously unknown "orange" compound [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n . The structure of [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n  has been determined from powder diffraction data and shown to consist of discrete Cu2I2 dimers bridged by the pyrazine ligands to form a 2D network. The structure presents a 4.4% of void space, which makes the compound unstable, and in the presence of solvent or vapor it transforms into its isomer [CuIpyz] n  also over time. We have also thoroughly explored the interconversion relationship between the three CuI derivatives.  summarizes all the possible conversions among the three coordination polymers, via mechanochemistry, thermal treatment, and slurry. It is worth stressing that coordination based on CuI and pyrazine has been previously studied by several research groups without detecting the phase [(CuI)2(pyz)2] n , which represents a rather extreme example of a compound that can only be obtained by mechanical grinding of the reactants and in complete absence of solvents.

elements.content: With the aim of expanding this chemistry further, we have also attempted substitution of pyrazine with another bridging ligand, namely, 4CN-py, obtaining the novel mixed-ligand compound [(CuI)­(4CN-py)2 py] n , whose complex behavior upon heating has also been rationalized.
elements.clean_text: With the aim of expanding this chemistry further, we have also attempted substitution of pyrazine with another bridging ligand, namely, 4CN-py, obtaining the novel mixed-ligand compound [(CuI)(4CN-py)2 py] n , whose complex behavior upon heating has also been rationalized.

elements.content: In summary, with this paper, we have provided further evidence of the importance of testing solvent-free nonsolution methods of preparation also within the area of coordination polymer chemistry with the awareness that structure determination can nowadays be tackled successfully by powder diffraction methods.
elements.clean_text: In summary, with this paper, we have provided further evidence of the importance of testing solvent-free nonsolution methods of preparation also within the area of coordination polymer chemistry with the awareness that structure determination can nowadays be tackled successfully by powder diffraction methods.

cln_elements.content:
CuI (0.788 mmol; 0.150 g) and pyrazine (0.394 mmol; 0.031 g) were ground together with ∼0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz, with a ball-to-powder mass ratio (BPR) of 10:1.8. The yellow crystalline powder obtained was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

Reaction in solution: [Cu2I2(pyz)] n was obtained following the procedure described in literature. CuI (300 mg, 1.57 mmol) dissolved in MeCN (20 mL) was added to a stirred solution of pyrazine (63 mg, 7.9 mmol) in MeCN (20 mL). A yellow precipitate formed immediately and was filtered off after the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The solid was dried in vacuo and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

Synthesis of [CuI­(pyz)]<sub>n</sub> Solid-State Reaction

CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and pyrazine (2 mmol; 0.162 g) were ground together with ∼0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:3.5). The red crystalline powder obtained was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum to eliminate the unreacted pyrazine, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

Solvothermal Reaction

The solvothermal reaction used differs from the published one. CuI (0,25 mmol; 0.043 g), pyrazine (1 mmol; 0.080 g), and 0.4 mL of acetonitrile were placed in 8 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave, heated to 120 °C for 30 min, and then cooled.

Synthesis of [(CuI)<sub>2</sub>(pyz)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>n</sub> Solid-State Reaction

CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and pyrazine (1.2 mmol; 0.100 g) were ground together for 40 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:2.9). The orange crystalline powder obtained was left under vacuum to eliminate the unreacted pyrazine and stored in a dry place to prevent the conversion to the [CuI­(pyz)] n isomer.

Synthesis of [(CuI)<sub>4</sub>(4CN-py)<sub>5</sub>]<sub>n</sub> Solid-State Reaction

CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and 4-CNpy (1.5 mmol; 0.156 g) were ground together with ∼0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:3.5). The product is a yellow crystalline powder. The product was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

Reaction in Solution

The product of [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n was obtained following the procedure described in literature. CuI (0.300 g, 1.57 mmol) dissolved in MeCN (20 mL) was added to a stirred solution of 4CN-py (0.204 g, 2 mmol) in MeCN (20 mL). A yellow precipitate formed immediately and was filtered off after the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The solid was dried under vacuum and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

Synthesis of [(CuI)<sub>2</sub>(4CN-py)­(pyz)]<sub>n</sub> Solid-State Reaction

[Cu2I2(pyz)] n (1 mmol; 0.115 g) and 4-cyanopyridine (2 mmol; 0.052 g) were ground together with four drops of acetonitrile for 40 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:1.7). The product is a yellow crystalline powder. The product was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cu2I2(pyz)]n 

Solid-State Reaction

CuI (0.788 mmol; 0.150 g) and pyrazine (0.394 mmol; 0.031 g) were ground together with ~0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz, with a ball-to-powder mass ratio (BPR) of 10:1.8. The yellow crystalline powder obtained was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

 Reaction in solution: [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  was obtained following the procedure described in literature. CuI (300 mg, 1.57 mmol) dissolved in MeCN (20 mL) was added to a stirred solution of pyrazine (63 mg, 7.9 mmol) in MeCN (20 mL). A yellow precipitate formed immediately and was filtered off after the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The solid was dried in vacuo and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

Synthesis of [CuI(pyz)]n 

Solid-State Reaction

CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and pyrazine (2 mmol; 0.162 g) were ground together with ~0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:3.5). The red crystalline powder obtained was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum to eliminate the unreacted pyrazine, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

Solvothermal Reaction

The solvothermal reaction used differs from the published one. CuI (0,25 mmol; 0.043 g), pyrazine (1 mmol; 0.080 g), and 0.4 mL of acetonitrile were placed in 8 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave, heated to 120 °C for 30 min, and then cooled.

Synthesis of [(CuI)2(pyz)2]n 

Solid-State Reaction

CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and pyrazine (1.2 mmol; 0.100 g) were ground together for 40 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:2.9). The orange crystalline powder obtained was left under vacuum to eliminate the unreacted pyrazine and stored in a dry place to prevent the conversion to the [CuI(pyz)] n  isomer.

Synthesis of [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5]n 

Solid-State Reaction

CuI (1 mmol; 0.190 g) and 4-CNpy (1.5 mmol; 0.156 g) were ground together with ~0.1 mL of acetonitrile for 20 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:3.5). The product is a yellow crystalline powder. The product was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

Reaction in Solution

The product of [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n  was obtained following the procedure described in literature. CuI (0.300 g, 1.57 mmol) dissolved in MeCN (20 mL) was added to a stirred solution of 4CN-py (0.204 g, 2 mmol) in MeCN (20 mL). A yellow precipitate formed immediately and was filtered off after the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The solid was dried under vacuum and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

Synthesis of [(CuI)2(4CN-py)(pyz)]n 

Solid-State Reaction

[Cu2I2(pyz)] n  (1 mmol; 0.115 g) and 4-cyanopyridine (2 mmol; 0.052 g) were ground together with four drops of acetonitrile for 40 min with a frequency of 20 Hz (BPR of 10:1.7). The product is a yellow crystalline powder. The product was washed with acetonitrile, dried under vacuum, and analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction.

cln_elements.content:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements (SCXD) were performed on an Oxford Xcalibur S diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.710 73 Å, and monochromator graphite at room temperature.

[(CuI)2(4CN-py)­(pyz)] n crystallizes as monoclinic P21/c with a = 10.2348(6) Å, b = 12.3289(4) Å, c = 8.8309(5) Å, and β = 109.605(6)° with volume 1049.73(9) Å3. SHELX97 was used for structure solution and refinement based on F 2. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were added in calculated positions. The refinement converged to R 1 (F, I > 2σ­(I) = 0.042 and WR2 (F 2, all data) = 0.136. The program Mercury was used for all graphical representations and for the calculated powder pattern. Additional crystallographic information is available in the .
cln_elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements (SCXD) were performed on an Oxford Xcalibur S diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å, and monochromator graphite at room temperature.

[(CuI)2(4CN-py)(pyz)] n  crystallizes as monoclinic P21/c with a = 10.2348(6) Å, b = 12.3289(4) Å, c = 8.8309(5) Å, and β = 109.605(6)° with volume 1049.73(9) Å3. SHELX97 was used for structure solution and refinement based on F 2. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were added in calculated positions. The refinement converged to R 1 (F, I > 2σ(I) = 0.042 and WR2 (F 2, all data) = 0.136. The program Mercury was used for all graphical representations and for the calculated powder pattern. Additional crystallographic information is available in the .

cln_elements.content: (a) The infinite chain of [(CuI)­(4CN-py)2 py] n with pyrazine bridging the copper iodide dimers and the 4CN-py almost perpendicular to the direction of the chain. (b) Packing view along the c axis.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  (a) The infinite chain of [(CuI)(4CN-py)2 py] n  with pyrazine bridging the copper iodide dimers and the 4CN-py almost perpendicular to the direction of the chain. (b) Packing view along the c axis.

cln_elements.content: XRPD-VT of [(CuI)­(4CN-py)2 py] n . The sample is stable up to 100 °C; at 120° the peaks characteristic of [Cu2I2(pyz)] n and [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n appear. The calculated patterns of the last two compounds are added to the diagram for comparison (labeled AGIYEU02 and KALHUA from the refcode of the CSD). At 150 °C the peak characteristic of CuI, at 2θ = 25 °C, is clearly visible.
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  XRPD-VT of [(CuI)(4CN-py)2 py] n . The sample is stable up to 100 °C; at 120° the peaks characteristic of [Cu2I2(pyz)] n  and [(CuI)4(4CN-py)5] n  appear. The calculated patterns of the last two compounds are added to the diagram for comparison (labeled AGIYEU02 and KALHUA from the refcode of the CSD). At 150 °C the peak characteristic of CuI, at 2θ = 25 °C, is clearly visible.

metadata.title:
Mechanochemistry, an Easy Technique to Boost the Synthesis
of CuI Pyrazine Coordination Polymers
